eniac.name: ENIAC (Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer)
eniac.overview: The first general-purpose electronic digital computer, ENIAC was a revolutionary machine that marked the beginning of the computer age.
eniac.historical_significance: ENIAC demonstrated that electronic computation was faster and more reliable than mechanical systems, paving the way for modern computing.

technical_details.programming: Programmed by manually setting switches and rewiring connections

development.developers: J. Presper Eckert and John Mauchly

eniac.legacy: ENIAC proved electronic computation was viable and influenced virtually every computer that followed.
interesting_facts: Programming required physical rewiring that could take days
Generated so much heat that nearby rooms needed cooling
Was classified as top secret during initial operation

univac1.name: UNIVAC I (UNIVersal Automatic Computer I)
univac1.overview: The first commercial computer produced in the United States, UNIVAC I gained fame by correctly predicting Eisenhower's presidential victory.
univac1.historical_significance: First computer to handle both numeric and alphabetic data, marking the transition from purely mathematical machines to business computers.

technical_details.architecture: Binary number system with magnetic tape storage
technical_details.memory: 1,000 words of mercury delay line memory
technical_details.storage: Magnetic tape system - revolutionary for the time
technical_details.weight_details: 13 tons (11,800 kg) for the central processor

development.developers: J. Presper Eckert and John Mauchly (ENIAC creators)
development.first_delivery: March 1951 to the U.S. Census Bureau

univac1.legacy: Established the commercial computer industry and demonstrated computers' potential beyond pure mathematics.
interesting_facts: Correctly predicted Eisenhower's victory with only 7% of votes counted
CBS initially didn't trust the prediction and delayed broadcasting it
Each system came with its own air conditioning unit

ibm704.name: IBM 704
ibm704.overview: IBM's first mass-produced computer with floating-point arithmetic, establishing IBM's dominance in the computer industry.
ibm704.historical_significance: First computer to use magnetic core memory and floating-point arithmetic, setting standards that lasted decades.

technical_details.memory: 4,096 or 32,768 words of magnetic core memory

ibm704.legacy: Enabled the development of FORTRAN and established IBM as the leading computer manufacturer.
interesting_facts: First computer to run the FORTRAN programming language
Used for early AI research including checkers-playing programs
Magnetic core memory was so reliable it remained standard until the 1970s
Required a specialized computer room with raised floors for cabling
